metadata.name: EEG recordings during sham neurofeedback in virtual reality
metadata.dataset_summary: This dataset contains EEG recordings from a sham neurofeedback experiment conducted in a virtual reality (VR) environment. The study investigated how feedback valence (positive, negative, or control) modulates alpha-band activity during an attentional task. EEG signals were recorded using a 32-channel SynAmps RT amplifier. Each participant completed four conditions: positive feedback, negative feedback, control, and resting-state (eyes open/closed). The original data was in .cnt format and converted to BIDS format. This dataset is publicly available on OpenNeuro.
metadata.task_description: Participants engaged in a sham neurofeedback experiment within a virtual reality environment. They completed four conditions: positive sham feedback (reinforcement), negative sham feedback (punishment), a control condition (observing VR without feedback), and a resting-state condition (alternating eyes open and closed). Each feedback condition involved four 2-minute blocks. Specific events were marked for block beginnings, increases/decreases in VR object brightness/volume, and eyes open/closed transitions during resting state.
authors: Collaborators from the Experimental and Computational Neuroscience Group
